Description: Black granite crown of the god Amun and rear pillar. On one side of the sculpture is the two feathered crown of Amun, the outer edges now damaged. The opposing side features the back-pillar of the statue shaped like the top of an obelisk. At the top section is an image of the goddess Maat in sunken relief, shown wearing a long dress and holding a was sceptre. Above her is the sun disc with two uraeus cobras extending down on either side, with several ankh symbols linked together and extending down the obelisk, framing the goddess. Below this are two slim columns of incised text bearing the royal titulary of Ramesses II. The edges of both the pillar and crown of Amun are chipped, and the top of the obelisk is slightly damaged. The object is now supported on a thick modern base.
Curator's comments: This undoubtedly came from a statue of the god Amun, and most likely was originally set up within a Theban context.
